message_1: Consider the language of arithmetic with only the symbols 0, 1, +, and $\times$. Let $\phi(x)$ be the formula $\exists y (x=y \times y)$. Determine the set of all natural numbers $n$ satisfying $\phi(n)$.
message_2:
The formula $\phi(x)$ states that there exists a natural number $y$ such that $x = y \times y$. In other words, $x$ is a perfect square. Therefore, the set of all natural numbers $n$ satisfying $\phi(n)$ is the set of all perfect squares:

$\{0, 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, 49, 64, 81, 100, 121, \dots\}$
